details.title: Approximation of mean time between failure when a system has periodic maintenance

p: Mitchell J. Mondro (M'92) received the B.S.E.E. degree (1985) from Lehigh University and the M.S.E.E. degree (1996) from Northeastern University.

He is Associate Section Leader of the Reliability and Maintainability Technical Center at The MITRE Corporation, Bedford, MA. His responsibilities include all reliability, maintainability, and availability activities during a system's concept, development, production, and deployment phases. Prior to working at MITRE, from 1985 to 1990 he was a reliability engineer with the Defense Systems Electronic Group of Texas Instruments. Some of his responsibilities included environmental stress screening, system-level failure analysis, and production-reliability assurance testing.

details.abstract: This paper describes a simple technique for estimating the mean time between failure (MTBF) of a system that has periodic maintenance at regular intervals. This type of maintenance is typically found in high reliability, mission-oriented applications where it is convenient to perform maintenance after the completion of the mission. This approximation technique can greatly simplify the MTBF analysis for large systems. The motivation for this analysis was to understand the nature of the error in the approximation and to develop a means for quantifying that error. This paper provides the derivation of the equations that bound the error that can result when using this approximation method. It shows that, for most applications, the MTBF calculations can be greatly simplified with only a very small sacrifice in accuracy.

references.title: Reliability Engineering

context.text: A mathematical equation that describes the MTBF of a system that has periodic maintenance performed at regular intervals is in reliability handbooks [1], [2]; however, its solution can be cumbersome for highly complex reliability models.

The MTBF for a system that has periodic maintenance at a regular interval can be described by [1], [2]:
